parsetree.*:
<root><template><title>Command</title><part><name>Comments</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="1"/><value> ofp </value></part><part><name>Game name</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>1.00</value></part><part><name>Game version</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>arg</name>=<value> global </value></part><part><name>Multiplayer Arguments</name>=<value>
</value></part><part><name>eff</name>=<value> local </value></part><part><name/>=<value> Effect in MP

</value></part><part><name>gr1</name>=<value> Triggers </value></part><part><name>GROUP1</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value> List of units that would activate given [[Triggers|Trigger]].

It returns nothing before the simulation started, i.e. in (undelayed) init.sqf files. Returns a '''[[Array#Array_references|pointer]]''' to the trigger's list after the simulation started.<br>Since this is just a ''reference'' this means that the value in your local variable will change as the content of the trigger area changes. To permanently copy the returned list to a different variable, use _mylist <ext><name>nowiki</name><attr/><inner>=</inner><close></nowiki></close></ext> +(list triggerOne).

The second example can be used inside the trigger (in that case, no need to name your trigger).

The list returned for trigger of type "Not present" is the same as that returned for type "present". 

'''NOTE:''' While the command can query any trigger, local or remote, the result will be only for the trigger condition set on the local client. See [[createTrigger]] for more info. </value></part><part><name>DESCRIPTION</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="4"/><value>[[Array]] <ext><name>nowiki</name><attr/><inner>=</inner><close></nowiki></close></ext>  '''list''' trigger </value></part><part><name>SYNTAX</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>p1</name>=<value> trigger: [[Object]] </value></part><part><name>PARAMETER1</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name index="5"/><value> [[Array]] or [[Nothing]] </value></part><part><name>RETURNVALUE</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________
		  
</value></part><part><name>x1</name>=<value> <code>_tlist <ext><name>nowiki</name><attr/><inner>=</inner><close></nowiki></close></ext> '''list''' _triggerOne; </code></value></part><part><name>EXAMPLE1</name>=<value>
</value></part><part><name>x2</name>=<value> <code>hint format ["%1", '''thislist''']; </code></value></part><part><name>EXAMPLE2</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="6"/><value> [[setTriggerActivation]], [[createTrigger]]</value></part><part><name>SEEALSO</name>=<value>

</value></part></template>

<h3 style="display:none">Notes</h3>
<dl class="command_description">
<comment><!-- Note Section BEGIN -->
</comment>
<dd class="notedate">Posted on March 6, 2013 - 14:15 (CEST)
<dt class="note">[[User:TeaCup|teaCup]]
<dd class="note">Calling [[list]] immediately after creating a trigger via [[createTrigger]] (and setting up activation, area, statements, timeout, etc..), will return <null> instead of an array. It seems the trigger needs about 1 second to initialise, after which it will behave as expected: returning an array of all the objects inside the trigger (the ones matching the criteria), or an empty array.

<comment><!-- Note Section END -->
</comment></dl>
